page.title: 01NORTH CHESHIRE COUNTRYSIDE
page.content: This area is one of typical Cheshire countryside - in the main flat and devoted to dairy farming. The fields are of average size, separated by hedges which are kept severely cut by machine in most cases. There are many hedgerow trees, mostly oak, and also numerous groups of trees, too small to be designated woodland. There is one small village, Antrobus, in the West. The area is dotted with prosperous looking farms and outbuildings - density, 3 or 4 per sq.Km., and isolated quality houses, sometimes halftimbered. There are 2 large properties. The NE corner is occupied by a small "stately home" - Arley Hall. This atands in its own parkland & is open to the public in the summer months. Its gardens are famous. In the south is Belmont Hall which is now an independent day school
